statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description:
Peja Stojakovic scored five of his 32 points in the final minute
as the Sacramento Kings edged the Seattle SuperSonics, 99-95,
for their 15th win in 16 games.

related.description:
Sacramento Kings forward Chris Webber was suspended Wednesday for one game and fined $7,500 for deliberately
throwing an elbow to the head of Utah's Jarron Collins last week.
related.linkText: Webber suspended one game, fined for throwing elbow
related.title: Webber's elbow at opponent's head deliberate
related.headline: Webber's elbow at opponent's head deliberate

article.headline: Kings top Sonics for 15th win in 16 games
article.linkText: Webber-less Kings keep rolling thanks to Peja and Co.
article.story:
SEATTLE (AP) -- The Sacramento Kings showed once again they're not just Chris Webber's team.
Stojakovic

Peja Stojakovic hit a 3-pointer and an 18-footer in the final minute and the Kings, playing without the suspended Webber, beat the Seattle SuperSonics 99-95 Thursday night. Stojakovic finished with 32 points as the Kings, who have the NBA's best record at 34-10, won for the 15th time in 16 games. "In those moments, I just feel I have to be more aggressive and more responsible," said Stojakovic, who was named an All-Star for the first time in his fourth year in the NBA this week. Stojakovic's 3-pointer with 52.3 seconds left gave the Kings a 95-92 lead. After rookie Vladimir Radmanovic missed a 3-pointer for Seattle with 35.3 seconds to go, Stojakovic hit an 18-footer with 16.6 seconds to play. Sonics coach Nate McMillan warned his players not to let Stojakovic beat them, and was disappointed they didn't listen. "Unbelievable," McMillan said. "You've got to get to the guy. We knew we had to get there and we didn't. He got open a split second and drilled it." Rashard Lewis of the Sonics made a 3-pointer with 13.4 seconds left. Seattle fouled Bobby Jackson, who made two free throws with 12 seconds to go. Lewis missed a 3-pointer for Seattle with 8.4 seconds remaining. Gary Payton scored 25 points and Vin Baker had 22, 20 in the first half, for the Sonics. Desmond Mason of Seattle had a season-high 13 rebounds. Adelman said stopping Baker in the second half was a key to his team's victory. Baker shot 9-for-15 in the first half and 1-for-6 in the second. "We were pretty soft in the first half all the way around and Vin was able to do pretty much what he wanted to do." Adelman said. "I thought he was throwing people all over the place to get his shots off, but we just wanted to get more active." Baker admitted he was frustrated in the second half. "They started doubling and they weren't allowing me to get to the middle," he said. "It was a tough second half." Webber was suspended for one game for throwing an elbow at Utah's Jarron Collins last Saturday. Webber missed his 24th game of the season. The Kings are 17-7 without Webber in the lineup and 17-3 with him. "We feel we can win if Chris isn't here and we've proven that," Sacramento coach Rick Adelman said. "We have seven guys averaging double figures and it shows there's a lot of guys on our team who can play." Scot Pollard of the Kings said playing well without Webber was a matter of pride. "We've proven to ourselves that we're a more mature team this year than we have been in years past," Pollard said. "We've dealt with some missing people and still come out on top most nights." The Kings, winning in Seattle for the first time since Dec. 29, 1999, shot 7-for-26 from 3-point range, but made four in the fourth quarter. Jackson made two 3s in the first 3 1/2 minutes and Doug Christie added the third with 6:43 to go to put Sacramento in front 87-82. Payton's 15-footer tied the score at 89. But Baker fouled out of the game with 2:40 left and Vlade Divac sank two free throws for the Kings. Radmanovic hit a 3-pointer with 2:21 to put the Sonics ahead 92-91 before Divac tied the score with a free throw with 1:29 left. Then Stojakovic made his two big shots. The Kings got 13 points and 10 rebounds from Divac, and 12 points each from Mike Bibby and Hedo Turkoglu. Lewis added 18 points for the Sonics, who lost their second straight home game after going 3-1 on a road trip. The Sonics hurt themselves with 10 turnovers in the third quarter, when they were limited to 17 points after scoring 59 points in the first half. "We turned the ball over and we beat ourselves," said Payton, who had three of Seattle's 16 turnovers. "I don't like to make excuses, but we beat ourselves with mistakes tonight. We gave this game away." Game notes
The Kings are 10-9 on the road and 24-1 at home. ... Sonics backup C Jerome James sat out the game because of back spasms. He hurt his back in practice on Wednesday and aggravated it at Thursday's shootaround. He was in uniform on the bench. ... McMillan said Calvin Booth, who was supposed to be the team's starting center this season after signing a $34 million, six-year contract as a free agent, will have the boot taken off his sprained right ankle sometime after the All-Star break on Feb. 10. Booth has been on the injured list since Dec. 12 and has played in only 15 games this season. McMillan said he wasn't sure if Booth would be able to play again this season. He has developed tendinitis in his right ankle.
